                Abdelhamid Abaaoud, also known as Abu Umar al-Baljiki, pictured here.  | POLITICO screenshot

            By 
Nick Gass

11/16/15 07:31 AM EST
Abdelhamid Abaaoud, the alleged mastermind of Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, told a magazine affiliated with the Islamic State earlier this year that it took several months to set up operations in Belgium.
"As you know, Belgium is a member of the crusader coalition attacking the Muslims of Iraq and Shām," Abaaoud told the jihadist publication Dabiq in February, also appearing under his nom de guerre of Abu Umar al-Baljiki.
Story Continued Below
"We faced a number of trials during the journey. We spent months trying to find a way into Europe, and by Allah’s strength, we succeeded in finally making our way to Belgium," Abaaoud said in the article. "We were then able to obtain weapons and set up a safe house while we planned to carry out operations against the crusaders."
The interview came weeks after a raid in Verviers, Belgium, failed to capture Abaaoud after dismantling the terror cell after searches in Molenbeek, a downscale district of Brussels where authorities are currently searching for the eighth suspect from last week's attacks.
None of those arrested during the raid had been his accomplices, he said.
"The intelligence knew me from before as I had been previously imprisoned by them," Abaaoud said. "After the raid on the safe house, they figured out that I had been with the brothers and that we had been planning operations together. So they gathered intelligence agents from all over the world – from Europe and America – in order to detain me. They arrested Muslims in Greece, Spain, France, and Belgium in order to apprehend me."
Abaaoud is also suspected of being linked to the foiled August train shooting, also in France.

title: Alleged Paris attacks mastermind boasted of planned 'operations' in February
